author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS |
title: Soccer: FIFA to begin investigation of Germany - Soccer
text:
The corruption scandal sweeping world soccer engulfed Germany as FIFA said Friday that it would investigate "very serious allegations" that voters were bribed to win the 2006 World Cup bid.
The latest claims of wrongdoing linked to soccer's governing body broke as suspended president Sepp Blatter went public with his fight to get his FIFA ethics case thrown out.
Blatter may have deepened the prospect of a long ban by admitting there was only a "gentleman's agreement" for the 2011 payment he authorized to UEFA president Michel Platini and which led to them both being suspended by FIFA last week after it emerged through a criminal investigation.
The investigation will now include looking into a report in news magazine Der Spiegel that Germany's 2006 World Cup bid committee established a slush fund of 10.3 million Swiss francs (then about $6 million) to bribe four of the 24 voters. Franz Beckenbauer, the former Germany great who headed the bidding committee, and Wolfgang Niersbach, the current president of the German football federation (DFB), as well as other high-ranking football officials were aware of the slush fund by 2005 at the latest, the report claimed.
ORLANDO CITY 2, NYC FC 1 (at Orlando, Fla.) â€” Kwame Watson-Siriboe gave New York City FC a 1-0 lead in the second minute of first-half stoppage time, but Cyle Larin scored twice in an 8-minute span in the second half to lead Orlando City to victory, keeping its playoff hopes alive. Orlando City (12-13-8) has won five straight games to move within a point of sixth-place Montreal for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.
